comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Do those shadows look appropriate for September? Sun a bit North of West? At 50 degrees-ish?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I don't think so. 50 degrees above the horizon would only ever be around lunchtime in september, so the sun would be south-ish. the closest you'd get on the 1st of september would be 45 degrees at half past one with the sun due south.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: It looks like it's around the summer solstice between four and five in the afternoon. The shadows are very hard to gauge though, as there's a pretty extreme curved camber on the road.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think it is more likely that O'Dea took this photo near the closure of the lines, in May/June 1940 than in any September.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Thanks Niall. Now added to our Flickr map. And apologies (to all of you) for my stupidity in blindly following the date on our catalogue for this one. Of course, 1950 is an impossible date for a Dublin tram photo. However, Wikipedia is wrong KLAXON! As [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] points out, the last #9 and #10 trams ran on Saturday, 1 June 1940. See this from the Irish Press on Monday, 3 June 1940: (as suggested by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley])
Dublin Trams Farewell Trip Many citizens who had been travelling to and fro on the Nos. 9 and 10 trams from Donnybrook to the Phoenix Park for over forty years turned out on Saturday night [i.e. Saturday 3 June] and gave the last tram a hearty send-off on its final journey to the Donnybrook terminus. Yesterday the service was replaced by ten new double-deck 'buses. The elimination of tram cars on all routes north of Nelson Pillar is now complete. The last tram left the Phoenix Park gates for Donnybrook at 11.30 on Saturday night. Some of the passengers who travelled in it for sentimental reasons, had been passengers on the first tram which opened the service just over 40 years ago. Accordions, saxaphones [sic] and violins played the tram "home" on its final run. The reception at Donnybrook was attended by over four hundred people who joined in singing "Auld Lang Syne".
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Put it down to sheer recklessness! Will not be so foolish again...

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Thanks for the link to the Newsletter - great to see the "feedback loop" working it's way back to the original catalog. However the "Cork hillsides" comment has firmly implanted a (notional) interaction in my head: 
  "Get out of my rhododendron bushes" cried the man. "It's all right" claimed the photographer, "I'm a Flickroonie". "Oh, that's OK then" he said, turning away.... "Wait - WHAT!?"

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Shame how run-down that neighbour has become.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] That rhododendron scenario was not imaginary: "... or by getting out and clambering through almost impregnable rhododendron bushes on Cork hillsides to find an exact location from which a photograph was taken..." Do you remember the church in Glengarriff and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03/]'s horticultural struggles? P.S. Have to hang head in shame that I've fallen behind with the "feedback loop", but I'm determined to catch up and stay caught up in the next couple of months, come hell or high water!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] "The elimination of tram cars on all routes north of Nelson Pillar is now complete" does this mean that there were tram cars still running south of Nelson Pillar after 3rd June 1940?

From this CIE page: The last Dublin tram to run was the No.8 to Dalkey, south Co.Dublin on the 3rd July 1949 which marked the closure of the system. The tram was followed by a huge crowd all the way to Dalkey and into the tram shed, for the last time, in sadness. A downside to this crowd was many got on the tram and took seats and anything that could be taken as memorabilia of the Dublin trams.

From [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/8224097998/]

comment.author: 36844288@N00
comment._content: The tram in front, 26, was one of the 'Luxury Saloons' built in 1931/33 - have two different dates for the same car in one reference! - and it was housed at Terenure Depot where it survived until closure of the Depot in 1948.
